form.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: a particular type of something that exists in many different varieties
form.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: the art forms of the twentieth century
The bicycle is an environment-friendly form of transport.
form.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: the way something is or appears to be
form.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: We oppose racism in all its forms.
Vitamin C can be taken in capsule or tablet form.
A typical training programme takes the form of a series of workshops.
People are bombarded with information in the form of TV advertising.
form.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: The female form is a thing of beauty.
the shadowy forms of the divers swimming below the boat
The main staircase was in the form of a big ‘S’.
form.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: an official document with spaces where you write information, especially about yourself
form.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: Application forms are available from the college.
Just complete the entry form (=write the answers to the questions on a form) and return it.
Fill in the form and send it back with your cheque.
form.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: the structure of a work of art or piece of writing, rather than the ideas it expresses, events it describes etc
form.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: the distinction between form and content
form.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: how well a sports person, team, musician etc is performing, or has performed recently
form.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: I have been greatly encouraged by the team’s recent form.
He had no qualms about dropping players he thought were off form  (=not performing well).
On current form he’s one of the top three players in the country.
He’s been in good form all this season.
form.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: examinations taken in the fourth form
form.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: a way of writing or saying a word that shows its number, tense etc. For example, ‘was’ is a past form of the verb ‘to be’.
form.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: if someone has form, they are known to the police because they have committed crimes in the past
form.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to establish an organization, committee, government etc
form.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: The winning party will form the government.
CARE was formed in 1946 and helps the poor in 38 countries.
form.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to be the thing, or one of the things, that is part of something else, often having a particular use
form.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: Love and trust should form the basis of a marriage.
The project forms part of a larger project investigating the history of the cinema.
The river formed a natural boundary between the two countries.
form.translation[1].definitions[1].note_: Form is a linking verb that links the subject of the sentence with a noun
The changes form part of a new curriculum
form.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: to start to exist, or make something start to exist, especially as the result of a natural process
form.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: The rocks were formed more than 4,000 million years ago.
By midnight ice was already forming on the roads.
Sulphur dioxide and nitrogen oxide combine to form acid rain.
form.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: to make something by combining two or more parts
form.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: In English the past tense of a verb is usually formed by adding ‘ed’.
form.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: to come together in a particular shape or line, or to make something have a particular shape
form.translation[1].definitions[4].examp: Film-goers began to form a line outside the cinema.
Cut off the corners of the square to form a diamond.
form.translation[1].definitions[5].defin: to establish and develop a relationship with someone
form.translation[1].definitions[5].examp: She seemed incapable of forming any relationships.
On returning to Boston, she formed a close friendship with her aunt.
form.translation[1].definitions[6].defin: to have a strong influence on how someone’s character develops and the type of person they become
form.translation[1].definitions[6].examp: Events in early childhood often help to form our personalities in later life.
form.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: an official document with spaces to answer questions and add information
form.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: We need to receive your application form by July 31.
There was no delivery address on the order form.
If you would just like to fill in a form we will process your request as quickly as possible.
You must complete the entry form and return it to us.
form.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: to establish a company, an organization, or a committee
form.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: Coca-Cola Amatil formed a joint venture with Tirtalina Group of Indonesia.
A committee was formed to look at the whole issue of bonuses for staff.
North American Vehicle Imports is a newly formed company with two principal partners.
form.translation[3].definitions[1].defin: when a company, organization, or committee forms, it is established
form.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: This was something that was not considered when the United Nations first formed.
form.translation[3].definitions[2].defin: to establish a relationship of working together
form.translation[3].definitions[2].examp: Electronic Data Systems Corp. and Australian-based Mincom formed an alliance to jointly market computer services and software to the mining industry.
